title: About
text:
Welcome to my corner of the internet! I’m Daniel, a passionate data scientist and analytics engineer with a deep-seated interest in leveraging data to drive social impact. Over the years, I’ve honed my skills in data science, analytics, and AI, and I’m excited to share my journey, projects, and insights with you.


I’m a seasoned data scientist with a rich background in statistics and machine learning. My work has always been inspired by a desire to help organizations solve their most pressing problems and drive meaningful change by leveraging on their data assets. As an avid learner, I continuously seek to expand my knowledge and expertise in data science, engineering, machine learning, and artificial intelligence.



My professional path has led me to explore various facets of data science and engineering. From integrating data from multiple data sources, developing compelling dashboards, to using machine learning to identify trends and patterns in data. My projects reflect my commitment to excellence and innovation. I’ve worked extensively with tools such as R, Python, Airbyte, and Power BI, always striving for efficiency and reproducibility in my workflows.



In pursuit of my vision to help organizations unlock the true potential of their data, I founded Spark Data Impact. Our mission is to provide top-notch services in data science, analytics, engineering, machine learning, and AI. We believe in the power of data to transform businesses and drive social good, and we are dedicated to making this a reality for our clients.



My portfolio includes a range of projects that highlight my expertise and passion. From creating from visualizing data, integrating data from various sources to machine learning, each project is a testament to my dedication and skill.



Beyond my technical work, I am committed to becoming a thought leader in data science and AI. I enjoy sharing thought-provoking philosophical content, inspired by thinkers like Socrates and Plato, to engage and inspire others. My goal is to foster a community where ideas and knowledge can be freely exchanged, driving collective growth and understanding.



When I’m not immersed in data, I have a keen interest in ancient Kenyan civilization, history, and law. These interests fuel my aspiration to one day pursue a career in politics, where I can leverage my expertise and insights to make a broader impact.

Thank you for visiting my website. I invite you to explore my blog, learn more about my projects, and join me in this exciting journey of discovery and innovation. Together, we can harness the power of data to create a better world.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
Hello and welcome to my new website, DanielMaangi.com!

I’m Daniel, a seasoned data scientist and analytics engineer with a keen interest in leveraging data science and artificial intelligence (AI) to solve complex problems and drive impactful insights. This website is a platform where I will share my journey, projects, and expertise in these exciting fields.


On this site, you’ll find a variety of content aimed at both beginners and experienced professionals in the fields of data science and AI. Here’s a glimpse of what I plan to share:


I’ll be highlighting some of the key projects I’ve worked on, including: - Machine Learning Models: Building predictive models to uncover trends and patterns in various datasets. - Data Engineering and ELT Processes: Developing efficient pipelines for data extraction, loading, and transformation using tools like Python and R. - Data visualization: Developing compelling dashboards using tools like Power BI, R shiny and Quarto.



Expect detailed, step-by-step guides on using various tools and technologies that I frequently work with, such as: - R and Python: Programming tips, libraries, and best practices for data science and machine learning. - Power BI: Creating impactful visualizations and dashboards to derive actionable insights. - ELT Pipelines: Workflow orchestration and best practices for data engineering.



I am committed to sharing my thoughts on the latest trends and innovations in data science and AI. My goal is to provide valuable insights that can help you stay ahead in this rapidly evolving field.




I encourage you to explore the website, read my blog posts, and engage with the content. Your feedback and interaction are invaluable as I continue to grow and share my knowledge.
Thank you for visiting DanielMaangi.com. Let’s harness the power of data and AI together to create a better world!

Stay tuned for upcoming posts and exciting content. If you have any questions or topics you’d like me to cover, feel free to reach out.
Best regards,
Daniel

title: Importing Data into R: A Comprehensive Guide
text:
Welcome to my first blog post on DanielMaangi.com! In this post, I’ll walk you through a variety of ways to import data into R, an essential skill for any data scientist. Whether you’re working with CSV files, Excel spreadsheets, databases, or web data, R has you covered with a wide range of functions and packages.


CSV (Comma-Separated Values) files are one of the most common formats for data storage. You can easily import CSV files into R using the read.csv() function.
# Importing a CSV file
data <- read.csv("path/to/yourfile.csv")
head(data)



Excel files are widely used in many organizations. The readxl package provides a convenient way to read Excel files.
library(readxl)
# Importing an Excel file
data <- read_excel("path/to/yourfile.xlsx", sheet = "Sheet1")
head(data)
For more complex Excel files, you can use the openxlsx package which provides additional functionality.
library(openxlsx)
# Importing an Excel file using openxlsx
data <- read.xlsx("path/to/yourfile.xlsx", sheet = 1)
head(data)



R can connect to various databases using packages like DBI and RSQLite for SQLite databases, or RMariaDB and RPostgreSQL for MariaDB and PostgreSQL databases respectively.
library(DBI)
# Connecting to a SQLite database
con <- dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), "path/to/yourdatabase.db")
# Importing data from a table
data <- dbReadTable(con, "your_table_name")
head(data)
# Don't forget to disconnect when you're done
dbDisconnect(con)



You can also import data from the web using the read.csv() function directly if the data is in CSV format, or the httr and rvest packages for more complex web scraping tasks.
# Importing a CSV file from a URL
url <- "http://example.com/yourfile.csv"
data <- read.csv(url)
head(data)
For web scraping:
library(httr)
library(rvest)
# Scraping data from a webpage
url <- "http://example.com"
webpage <- read_html(url)
data <- webpage %>% html_nodes("your_css_selector") %>% html_text()
head(data)



library(jsonlite)
# Importing JSON data
url <- "http://example.com/yourfile.json"
data <- fromJSON(url)
head(data)

title: Importing Data into R: A Comprehensive Guide
text:
Welcome to my first blog post on DanielMaangi.com! In this post, I’ll walk you through a variety of ways to import data into R, an essential skill for any data scientist. Whether you’re working with CSV files, Excel spreadsheets, databases, or web data, R has you covered with a wide range of functions and packages.


CSV (Comma-Separated Values) files are one of the most common formats for data storage. You can easily import CSV files into R using the read.csv() function.
# Importing a CSV file
data <- read.csv("path/to/yourfile.csv")
head(data)



Excel files are widely used in many organizations. The readxl package provides a convenient way to read Excel files.
library(readxl)
# Importing an Excel file
data <- read_excel("path/to/yourfile.xlsx", sheet = "Sheet1")
head(data)
For more complex Excel files, you can use the openxlsx package which provides additional functionality.
library(openxlsx)
# Importing an Excel file using openxlsx
data <- read.xlsx("path/to/yourfile.xlsx", sheet = 1)
head(data)



R can connect to various databases using packages like DBI and RSQLite for SQLite databases, or RMariaDB and RPostgreSQL for MariaDB and PostgreSQL databases respectively.
library(DBI)
# Connecting to a SQLite database
con <- dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(), "path/to/yourdatabase.db")
# Importing data from a table
data <- dbReadTable(con, "your_table_name")
head(data)
# Don't forget to disconnect when you're done
dbDisconnect(con)



You can also import data from the web using the read.csv() function directly if the data is in CSV format, or the httr and rvest packages for more complex web scraping tasks.
# Importing a CSV file from a URL
url <- "http://example.com/yourfile.csv"
data <- read.csv(url)
head(data)
For web scraping:
library(httr)
library(rvest)
# Scraping data from a webpage
url <- "http://example.com"
webpage <- read_html(url)
data <- webpage %>% html_nodes("your_css_selector") %>% html_text()
head(data)



library(jsonlite)
# Importing JSON data
url <- "http://example.com/yourfile.json"
data <- fromJSON(url)
head(data)

title: Importing Data into R: A Comprehensive Guide
text:
Conclusion
R offers a plethora of options for importing data from various sources, making it a powerful tool for data scientists. Mastering these methods will allow you to handle data from different formats and sources efficiently.
Stay tuned for more posts where I’ll dive deeper into data manipulation, analysis, and visualization in R. If you have any questions or topics you’d like me to cover, feel free to reach out.
Happy coding!
Best regards,
Daniel
